Award.AwardTitle: Education and Public Outreach at the Soudan Underground Lab
Award.AbstractNarration: With this award funds are provided for partial support of the public outreach program at the Soudan Mine Underground Laboratory, the country's only operational underground high energy particle physics and astrophysics facility. The Lab is hosted in a Minnesota State Park, where each year about 4,000 of the Park's visitors venture 2,341 feet underground to see the facility, the MINOS and CDMS-II experiments, and to learn about neutrinos and Dark Matter. The proposed work is for two high school science teachers and two undergraduate interns to work in the lab over the summer, and an outreach coordinator who will contribute year round. Their primary duty is to help give the twice-daily "physics tours" and explain the lab and the science to visitors of the park. They then use this experience and their science education skills to improve the lab's outreach program and develop lesson plans and educational materials for use by the many school groups which visit the lab on field trips during the school year. They also participate in research projects with the experiments in the lab including MINOS and CDMS. The funds will also support the annual Open House. Most years since 1989, the lab has been open, free to the community at large for a day in the spring. Special displays are set up and hundreds of visitors are shown around the lab by the participating scientists. This gives the lab a high, positive profile in the community as well as share the science. The posters and educational materials developed are available on the website and used throughout the year.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was the outreach program at the Soudan Underground Laboratory in Soudan, MN. A major portion of this support was for undergraduate interns and high school teachers who led summer tours of the laboratory, including the two major experiments hosted at the lab: the MINOS neutrino oscillation experiment and the CDMS cryogenic dark matter search. Approximately 2500 people took tours at the lab each of three summers, plus a record crowd of 632 people for the one-day, free open house in May 2010. In addition to the public contact and website content, this project provides an opportunity for several different undergraduates and high school teachers per year to learn about these projects in depth, and take that experience back to their classroom and their future science and education careers.

 

The people contributing to the project created new, or updated and improved previous outreach materials, including posters and web content, and ran a series of prototype tours at the new NOvA neutrino experiment site in Ash River, MN, in preparation for the full operation of that new experiment in 2013. In addition, this project supported the outreach team to not just talk with the public about the scientific program at the Laboratory, they engaged in projects with the operation of the experiments or analysis of the data from these experiments, supporting the research program directly.
